thread.title: Former Louisville players acknowledge stripper parties, admit to having paid sex
thread.title_full: Former Louisville players acknowledge stripper parties, admit to having paid sex

author: Travis Durkee
title: Former Louisville players acknowledge stripper parties, admit to having paid sex
text:
Former Louisville players acknowledge stripper parties, admit to having paid sex Sporting News 6 hrs ago Travis Durkee As allegations swirl around the Louisville basketball program, at least five former players and recruits have admitted to attending on-campus parties where dancers, and sometimes sex, were provided for recruits and players.
AdChoices In an extensive report by ESPN’s Outside The Lines , five former Cardinals players admitted to attending parties that included strippers (who stripped naked) provided to them by former Louisville player and graduate assistant Andre McGee. One player said he had sex with one of the strippers at the party after McGee paid her.
MORE: What we learned from 'Breaking Cardinal Rules' | Sex scandals in sports
"I knew they weren't college girls. It was crazy,” one former recruit told Outside the Lines. “It was like I was in a strip club."
“ Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen ” author Katina Powell said she provided the paid escorts for the program over a four-year period and snuck them into the basketball program’s dorm to dance and oftentimes have sex with the players for an agreed-upon sum of money.
In an ESPN.com report last week, a former player admitted to attending parties in the Billy Minardi Hall dormitory "one or two times" but insisted no one paid for sex.
Three of the five players in the Outside the Lines report said they attended parties as recruits and also when they played for Louisville.
Yahoo has reported that McGee paid Powell more than $10,000 from 2010-2014.
Outside the Lines has confirmed Powell sent text messages to McGee and confirmed a wire transfer of money from McGee to Powell “on one occasion.”
"I couldn't make this up if I wanted to," Powell told Outside the Lines. "I have no reason, or have the need, to lie on anyone. Everything I'm saying is 100 percent the truth."
Read the full Outside the Lines report here .
